data.title: Jazz Standards Songs and Instrumentals (Invitation)
data.meta_description: JazzStandards.com: The premier site for the history and analysis of the standards jazz musicians play the most.
data.text:
Bronislau Kaper composed the score for the 1950 film A Life of Her Own, starring Lana Turner as a model whoâs having an affair with a married man played by Ray Milland. Kaperâs film score was nominated for a Golden Globe award, but the picture did not do well at the box office. However, the lush and haunting score was so appealing that it was used for a second film in 1952, Invitation, starring Dorothy Maguire and Van Johnson. Paul Francis Webster wrote the lyric for Kaperâs main theme, called simply âInvitation.â So although Kaper wrote the melody in 1950, the songâs date is usually given as 1952.

Webster had collaborated with Duke Ellington on 1941âs âI Got It Bad and That Ainât Goodâ and won two Academy Awards with Sammy Fain for âSecret Loveâ and âLove Is a Many-Splendored Thingâ and another with Johnny Mandel for âThe Shadow of Your Smile.â Kaper (whose first name is sometimes spelled âBronislawâ) won an Oscar for his 1953 score for the film Lili and wrote two other songs which have entered the jazz repertoire: âOn Green Dolphin Streetâ and âAll Godâs Chillun Got Rhythm.â

Kaperâs unforgettable melody is admirably matched by Websterâs equally haunting and somewhat mysterious lyric:

Wherever I go youâre the glow of temptation,

Glancing my way in the grey of the dawn

And always your smile holds that strange invitation

Then you are gone

Where oh where have you gone?

George Shearing arranged âInvitationâ for piano, and Frank Mantooth wrote a Latin arrangement of the song. Rosemary Clooney recorded it in 1963 with a lush background arranged by Nelson Riddle. Without ever having charted, âInvitationâ seeped into the jazz standard repertoire. Just since 2000 it has been recorded by vocalists Freddy Cole, Andy Bey, Patricia Barber, and the New Four Freshmen; pianists Rene Rosnee, Randy Halberstadt, and Steve Kuhn; saxophonists Herb Geller, Vincent Herring, and Don Braden; trumpeter Brian Lynch, bassist Ray Drummond, and Bob Florence Limited Edition. It is also featured on the soundtrack of For Love or Country: The Arturo Sandoval Story.
